Description: Cast figure of the funerary god Osiris in copper alloy; depicted as mummiform and standing on small square base; holding the sceptre Heka and the flail Nekhekh against his chest, hands side by side; traditional insignia of power; wearing the Atef crown, composed of the white crown flanked by two ostrich feathers, with uraeus on front and horizontal ram horns; feathers, beard, and insignia of power detailed with small diagonal and horizontal incisions; tang beneath base; underside of base slightly hollow; protruding parts of crown on left and ends of flail and hook broken off, as well as end of tang; almost complete and well preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
According to Philadelphia register card, original number E 139. = EEF distribution list Philadelphia, no. 13.

The early excavations at Naukratis provided many bronze figures of Osiris. Some of them originated from a cache of bronzes found in a building located in the southern part of the city: it contained nineteen statuettes of Osiris, twelve of which were complete (Petrie 1886, 41-42). Osiris is by far the most represented deity in the corpus of bronze figures from Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). Bronzes representing Osiris, as well as the other members of the Osirian triad - Isis and Harpokrates, are conspicuous in Late Period and Ptolemaic bronze votive deposits all over Egypt (see for example the large caches from North Saqqara where members of the Osirian triad represent three quarter of the bronze figures: Emery 1970, 6). The Osirian cult is important in the saite nome, and particularly in Sais itself as stressed by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 445), but also on a more local scale (Masson 2015). This figure belongs to the type 85 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss, a type that occurs in the Memphite region, Sais, Tell Nebesheh, Bubastis and Athribis; this type already appears in the 25th dynasty and goes on in the Late Period (Weiss 2012, 175-177, 641-649, Pl. 24f-j, Typ 85, see esp. Nr. 482 for this specimen). Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Weiss 2012 / Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland (p. 648, Nr. 482)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.118) (phase 3)
